I realize the gravity gradient is incredibly small, but wouldn't it be possible to determine the distance from the center of the earth by measuring the gravity gradient in free fall?  I'm reminded of the buried line tracers that detect the field gradient and compute the distance to the buried line.  Since the gravitational field falls off with an inverse square, a precise enough (if it's even possible) measurement would be able to determine an actual distance without even knowing the mass of the object in question.

I mention her because Congress needs more women lawmakers, and more women who know science and teach it.(Hopefully, the 'more' women will be Progressive types).
BTW, another plus for women in Science, the Editor-in Chief of the AAAS Science mag is none other than Marcia McNutt(no name jokes, please), And can you guess it, and why I mention her? 2 reasons, she's a woman in science, but first she's a Geophysicist, who has done work at Scripps Inst of Oceanography, however she's had the dubious distinction of saying the XL pipeline is preferred over trains and trucks. Pluses and minuses, I guess, but I'm sure it's a bigger issue than headlines we may see.

This is an interresting topic, allthough, it bothers me how many people tend to call it "zero gravity" (like Emily does). The thing is that there is allways gravity, and they are simply just experiencing zero G-force. It is the same with astronauts that experience zero "G-force". They fall down towards the earth but at the same time move sideways of it. That causes them to orbit around the earth and experience zero G-force, and NOT zero gravity.
